DOCNAME: OSMANI AND OTHERS v. "THE FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA"
TEXT: The applicant , PERSON , was born in DATE . He lives in GPE , the Former GPE . He is represented before the ORG by Mr PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE , GPE .

At the DATE local elections the applicant was elected mayor of ORG . On DATE ORG took a decision implementing section CARDINAL of the Statute of the municipality of GPE on the use of flags . It provided that the NORP and NORP flags should be placed along with the NORP flag in front of FAC . Other public institutions were also informed to display the NORP and NORP flags during public holidays .

On DATE the Government and a political party requested ORG to examine the constitutionality and legality of ORG decision on the ground that neither the LAW nor the respective law granted power to the municipalities to regulate the display of flags . On DATE ORG declared the request for examination of the constitutionality and legality of LAW of the Statute of the municipality of ORG admissible and , by way of an interim order , suspended the validity of all ensuing decisions . ORG was served with the decision on DATE .
On DATE the applicant organised a meeting at which the NORP flag was not flown but the flag of GPE was displayed and the NORP national anthem was played . At the meeting he , inter alia , stated :

“ Dear citizens of ORG and all NORP from where ever you come . Your gathering demonstrates once again that we started slowly but surely to fulfil what we have promised in the electoral campaign in the field of politics , culture and economy .
Each NORP , wherever he or she lives has CARDINAL thought , CARDINAL idea , CARDINAL stance concerning the national issue , the issue of the NORP language , the flag or the University ...

This should be a clear message for all , for [ the President ] PERSON , [ the Prime Minister ] PERSON , ORG that nobody should touch the NORP flag . You are right [ the citizens shout : “ we will sacrifice our lives but not the flag ” ] we will sacrifice our lives but not the flag . We shall not accept any decision by ORG which is entirely a political one , this institution which should protect the constitutionality and the legality but in fact violates LAW , LAW that they have adopted and laws which they have adopted without asking us , it is for us to decide on our own rights . It is not for them to decide .

Many troops flew the NORP flag , i.e. , Partisans’ , Balists’ [ NORP movement which occupied the western part of the Former GPE during the Second World War ] and other NORP troops which were always fighting for the liberation of our territories . Our territories in [ the Former GPE of ] GPE are our territories , this should be acknowledged once for all and on these territories our flag shall always be flown .

We were not given our mandates to execute the policy of the Government [ of the Former GPE ] of GPE , but to do what you have wished to be done and that is certainly what we are going to do , because we were not elected by the Government [ of the Former GPE ] of GPE , the ORG or the President ...

The [ Government ’s ] black hand covered with blood ORG DATE , their black hand wishes to cover with blood our national flag DATE , but they have first to think thoroughly as we are going to reply to a slap with a slap .

I gave them a clear message that as long as I am in the FAC nobody shall ever touch the NORP flag - they may go ahead , they may suspend me and the councillors of FAC , but they shall never touch the flag , since we were not elected to remain quiet in our offices , DATE we are ready to give up our duties and offices , shall we do so ?
During the election campaign I promised you that ORG will become an NORP town and so it will be .

It shall [ become an NORP town ] by an official display of the flag , the official use of the NORP language and by putting up the signs of the stores in NORP language , and [ by establishing ] many other institutions with other NORP municipalities . We shall do it within the framework of the project of the regionalisation .
It should be clear that the NORP flag is the eternal symbol of the NORP .

Finally , I wish to thank you all and I promise you once more that we shall hold to the issue of the flag , the language , the ORG and to many other NORP projects until the end , that we will soon turn them into reality notwithstanding the will of whomever , we shall abide by your political will and the only court that we shall obey eventually is the NORP nation and nobody else .
Long live the NORP flag ” .
On DATE ORG informed ORG of its decision not to implement ORG interim order of CARDINAL DATE emphasising that the removal of the flags would lead to an inter - ethnic conflict .

On DATE a group of citizens tried to remove the NORP flag from the front of FAC which led to a fight between the citizens . Following this , the applicant outside his competence as a mayor , organised armed shifts for the protection of the NORP flag .

Furthermore , he also acting outside of his competence as a mayor and out of law , set up central crisis headquarters with several regional branches . A list of civilians of NORP ethnic origin with special responsibilities was drawn up and money was allocated for different activities , such as propaganda and communication , shelters for injured people , etc .
On DATE the applicant warned ORG that the interim order of CARDINAL DATE would lead to an inter - ethnic conflict .

On DATE ORG abrogated CARDINAL of FAC on the ground that ORG had exceeded its power when it had regulated the display of the flags by its statute as it had not been empowered to do so by the LAW or by law .
On DATE , at TIME , the police removed the flags from the front of FAC . ORG on DATE gave , inter alia , the following account :
During the searches carried out in GPE ... FAC firearms were found , for which their holders did not have a licence ... ”
In footnote no . CARDINAL it was stated :

“ CARDINAL armed persons , ... CARDINAL in ORG [ who were watching over the NORP flags ] were detained and the following firearms were confiscated - semi - automatic guns “ PERSON without a number , calibre PERSON ; PERSON , model no . CARDINAL , without a number , calibre CARDINAL ; and “ TT ” -CARDINAL , calibre MONEY which were found in the kitchen , the toilet and the corridor of the private office of the chairman of the FAC ” - end of the footnote .
The report goes on :

“ At TIME ... , without any reason a group of CARDINAL citizens , by use of physical violence , projectiles [ rocks and stones ] , metal sticks and “ chemical substances ” [ Molotovs’ cocktails and teargas ] attacked the police [ apparently positioned nearby FAC ] and ... breached the public order and peace in the town .

The police used “ chemical substances ” AF-CARDINAL and AG-CARDINAL [ teargas ] , truncheons and physical force . The public order was quickly restored , but other people from the nearby villages [ who arrived ] in an organised manner joined the crowed which became larger . According to our estimations , at TIME a crowed of CARDINAL people gathered in front of FAC .

... at around TIME five persons were detained , CARDINAL of whom were citizens of GPE and all CARDINAL bottles with Molotovs’ cocktails were found . Since [ the leaders ] could no longer use Molotovs’ cocktails to heat - up the crowed they started shouting : “ GPE , GPE ” .

At around TIME the first smoke bomb was thrown nearby the positions of the police , and after a while the second smoke bomb was thrown [ at the police ] . The visibility reduced by the smoke bombs provoked the extremists to open fire with automatic guns .
... one of the policeman was seriously injured and urgently taken to hospital .

After TIME of intensive firing from both sides , the Ministry had not received any information that anybody from the extremists or from the crowed had been killed or injured in the interim . No deaths or injuries were reported until then and later [ as a result of ] the request of the parents of CARDINAL victims an autopsy was not ordered by the investigating judge , therefore , the possibility to clarify the circumstances ( time , place , manner , etc . ) surrounding their deaths was excluded .
Around TIME the firing had stopped and the police restored the peace in the town .

... the police searched the private offices of the chairmen of FAC ... in ORG and the houses of the CARDINAL “ guards ” of the flag in front of FAC ( CARDINAL automatic guns and a big quantity of ammunition were found ) .

In the private office of the chairman of the Gostivar Town Hall the police , inter alia , found documents concerning the “ crises headquarters and its regional branches ” which were set up in case of an attempt to remove the NORP flag . The way the headquarters were structured justifies the fear that [ the people involved were ready ] to put up armed resistance .
In footnote no . CARDINAL of the report it was said :

“ In CARDINAL of the buildings from where it was fired on the police , large quantities of medicines and other medical equipment for an intravenous drip , analgesic drugs , antibiotics , [ medicines ] against dehydration , ampoules against excessive bleeding , etc , were found ... ” - end of the footnote .
The report further continues :
“ In the ORG hospital CARDINAL patients seriously or slightly injured were registered DATE ...
On DATE CARDINAL injured persons requested medical assistance at FAC ... On DATE other persons requested medical assistance at FAC ...

On DATE the police searched the applicant ’s home and seized CARDINAL guns and some documents , including DATE on the set up of the central crises headquarters and its regional branches ; a list of persons from different municipalities who were responsible for different tasks , i.e. , communication and propaganda , shelters for injured , finances , transport and security of the flag ; and a copy of the applicant ’s speech delivered on DATE .

The police had requested the applicant several times to address the citizens , but the applicant had allegedly agreed to do so only after the NORP flag was removed from the front of FAC , the police forces withdrawn and detained persons released . At that occasion the applicant also allegedly stated that DATE the NORP flag would be flown as the official one and not only as the flag of a minority . Around TIME he addressed the people via a local TV station following which the riots stopped .

On DATE the applicant was detained pending trial and on DATE he was charged with stirring up national , racial and religious hatred , disagreement and intolerance by a public official and with a serious case of organised resistance and the non - execution of a decision or an order of a ORG institution . He was released on DATE .
ORG held hearings on CARDINAL , DATE and DATE .

In addition to hearing several witnesses , the court examined , inter alia , typed and hand - written originals as well as a translation of the applicant ’s speech , a video - tape of the aforementioned meeting , TIME and other documents on the setting up of central crisis headquarters with regional branches , shelters for the injured and a list of persons who took part in those activities .

On DATE ORG found the applicant guilty of : ( a ) stirring up , as a public official , national , racial and religious hatred , disagreement and intolerance for which he was sentenced to DATE of imprisonment ; ( b ) organising resistance against a lawful decision or activity of a ORG institution for which he was sentenced to CARDINAL years’ term of imprisonment ; and ( c ) non - execution , as a public official , of a ORG decision for which he was sentenced to CARDINAL PERSON term of imprisonment . The overall sentence was DATE and CARDINAL months’ term of imprisonment .

The offence of stirring up , as a public official , national , racial and religious hatred , disagreement and intolerance had been made out by the failure of the applicant , who had been an elected mayor , to inform ORG and the central Government that the decision to display the flags of GPE and GPE in front of FAC had been unconstitutional . He had implemented such an unlawful decision and had instructed all other public institutions to display the respective flags during the public holidays . He had refused to implement ORG interim order and decision and had organised a public meeting under the motto “ to defend the official use of the national flag ” at which the anthem of GPE had been played and the flag of GPE displayed .
Moreover , at the meeting he , inter alia , had stated :

“ we shall give our lives but not our flag ” , “ we do not recognise the decisions of the Constitutional Court ” ; ” “ The NORP flag was flown in front of many troops , i.e. , partisans’ , ORG [ NORP movement which occupied western part of the Former GPE during the Second World War ] and in front of other NORP troops which were always fighting for the liberation of our territories . Our territories in [ the Former GPE of ] GPE are our territories , this should be acknowledged once and for all and on these territories our flag will always be flown ” .

The court held that the applicant had called and organised the citizens of NORP origin to protect the respective flag with their lives , thereby , he had encouraged the violent events of DATE in which CARDINAL lives had been lost , many citizens injured and considerable damage caused . He had caused a feeling of insecurity and fear among the citizens of NORP origin . He had been aware in advance of the serious consequences which his speech might have and had actually provoked .

There had been a connection between the meeting of DATE and the events of DATE as it was clear from the evidence that the set up of the central crisis headquarters , shelters for the injured , TIME shifts and different strategies how to defend the flag had been planned and undertaken by the applicant .

Furthermore , the CARDINAL villagers who had been “ on duty ” to protect the flag on TIME gave evidence that a person who had identified himself as being a messenger of the applicant had asked CARDINAL of them , PERSON , to be on the TIME shift of CARDINAL DATE for the protection of the flag of GPE . For this purpose he had received a proxy with the stamp and signature of the applicant . The name of the second witness PERSON had also been put on the proxy . In the Town Hall Mr F. and Mr B. had been instructed by PERSON from the village of PERSON to watch over the flag until TIME and to inform the applicant in case they noticed something suspicious . Mr F. had been in a possession of a gun - “ PERSON ” , calibre CARDINAL with no licence .

The court concluded that the applicant was determined to protect the flag of GPE despite ORG decision . As an elected mayor of a town with mixed population instead of promoting an inter - ethnic co - operation and tolerance he had called the citizens of NORP ethnic origin to resist a lawful police action and had organised armed resistance against the implementation of ORG decision .

The applicant appealed to ORG . He argued that his rights to freedom of expression and freedom of assembly guaranteed by ORG DATE had been violated . The main reason to organise the meeting of CARDINAL DATE had been to express his discontent with ORG interim order of CARDINAL DATE . The violent events of DATE had not been provoked by his speech and actions but by the police action . The “ civil night shifts ” had been organised to watch over and report if somebody or the police attempted to remove the flags .

On DATE ORG upheld the lower court ’s judgment . The sentence for having stirred up , as a public official , national , racial and religious hatred , disagreement and intolerance was reduced to CARDINAL years’ imprisonment ; the sentence for having organised resistance against a lawful decision or activity of a ORG institution was reduced to CARDINAL GPE imprisonment ; and the sentence for not having executed , as a public official , ORG decision was reduced to CARDINAL years’ imprisonment on the ground that the applicant had no previous criminal record . The applicant ’s overall sentence was reduced to DATE imprisonment .

The court held that the applicant was not punished because he had expressed his opinion or organised an assembly , but because he , as a public official , had stirred up national , racial and religious hatred , disagreement and intolerance by his speech of DATE addressed to the citizens of NORP origin by which he encouraged a group of citizens to criminal activities . As a result there were public riots and disorder on DATE and DATE . Furthermore , he , as a public official , had refused to execute ORG decision and had organised resistance against a lawful decision and activity of a ORG institution . In particular , he had planned and set up central and regional branches of the crisis headquarters and armed shifts for the protection of the flag of GPE .
On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant ’s appeal on points of law , holding that the lower courts’ judgments were precise , consistent and reasoned .
On DATE the applicant availed himself of his right to submit constitutional complaint concerning the alleged violation of his right to freedom of expression .

On DATE ORG dismissed his complaint . The court found , inter alia , that : a ) the applicant had not informed ORG and the Government about the unconstitutionality of the decision to display the flags of ORG and GPE and had implemented it ; b ) had not implemented the interim order of ORG DATE ; c ) at the public meeting which had been organised by him and where he delivered his speech , the NORP anthem had been played , the flag of GPE flown , but the NORP flag had not been flown ; d ) from the content of his speech it was clear that he had conveyed a message that the NORP population was endangered , that it should fight to defend the flag and promised that ORG would become an NORP town ; e ) organised armed shifts and central and regional headquarters for the protection of the flag of GPE and planned resistance in case of an attempt for its removal ; and f ) prompted by the applicant ’s speech and actions the citizens of NORP origin offered armed resistance on DATE which resulted in CARDINAL lives being lost , many people injured and substantial material damage being caused .
The court , inter alia , stated :

[ The limits of the right to respect for freedom of expression as provided by LAW read as a whole , as well as , the Convention are based on ] the enforcement of the principle of legality set out in LAW ( “ No person may be punished for an action which was not considered as an offence by law , or other legislation prior to being committed , and for which no sanction has been foreseen ” ) together with the proscription of actions that impinge upon the rights and freedoms of others and other values guaranteed by LAW [ that should be ] proportionate to the need in a NORP society . ... this is foreseen in LAW of GPE , which sets out the basis and limits of the criminal punishment , [ and ] under which “ The protection of freedoms and rights of peoples and of other fundamental values , and the enforcement of sanctions [ that should be ] proportionate to the need to prevent crime provide for the basis and definition of the legal characterisation of criminal offences and sanctions .

In particular , the way the applicant made a presentation in public and expressed his opinion , the words he used , the place of his appearance , his position , the aim he wished to achieve and the consequences ... , as well as , the actions he undertook before and after the protest [ examined ] as a whole represent an action which is directed against legal order as basis for the enjoyment of all freedoms and rights , and it matches the legal characterisation of the criminal offences of which he had been found guilty and sentenced . The circumstance that the criminal offences had been made out by way of action which at its surface appeared to be an enjoyment of the right of freedom of expression does not represent a ground to justify the applicant ’s guilt concerning the criminal offences committed , as it transpires from the facts of the case that his action had resulted in loss of the very content of the public expression as guaranteed and protected by LAW . The reason for that , as transpires from the facts of the case , is that the applicant with his publicly expressed opinion had not given his intellectual or political stance , nor had [ his action ] represented a way of intellectual or political persuasion of the persons attending the assembly , but had directly called the citizens of NORP ethnic origin to disobey or , evenmore , fight against public order , thus causing intolerance , friction and hatred among the citizens of ORG in the situation of already existing sensitive inter - ethnic tension , and the feeling of insecurity among the citizens of NORP ethnic origin , as well as , among the citizens of NORP ethnic origin , which all together had the event of DATE as its tragic epilogue ... ”
On DATE the ORG adopted LAW following which the applicant was granted amnesty and dispensed from having to serve his prison sentence . He was released on DATE after having served DATE and DATE .

LAW guarantees the freedom of belief , conscience , opinion and public expression . LAW guarantees the right to peaceful assembly . LAW and CARDINAL provide that ORG is competent to decide on the conformity of LAW and decisions with the LAW and the laws , whereas § CARDINAL of the same Article sets out ORG competence to deal with complaints from individuals concerning violation of their rights and freedoms to communication , conscience , opinion and public expression , political association and activities , as well as prohibition of discrimination on the grounds of gender , race , religion or national , political or social affiliation .

Article CARDINAL provides , inter alia , that the citizens directly and through representatives participate in the decision - making in respect of the issues of local relevance . This concerns in particular : the urban planning , communal activities , culture , sport , social security and child care , nursery , primary education , basic health care and other fields determined by the respective law in the units of local self - government .
Article CARDINAL on stirring up national , racial and religious hatred , disagreement and intolerance , as far as relevant , provides as follows :

“ CARDINAL . Any person who stirs up national , racial and religious hatred , disagreement and intolerance by coercion , ill - treatment , duress , who insults national , ethnic and religious symbols , or damages monuments and cemeteries , or in any other way stirs up national , racial and religious hatred , disagreement and intolerance shall be punished with CARDINAL to CARDINAL years’ imprisonment .

CARDINAL . A person who commits the offence set out in LAW of this section by abusing his official position or power and thereby causes riots and violence against people or huge material damage shall be punished with CARDINAL to CARDINAL years’ imprisonment . ”
Article CARDINAL on the non - execution of a judicial decision , as far as relevant , provides as follows :
CARDINAL . Any official or person who is under a duty to execute a decision of ORG and who refuses to do so shall either be fined or punished with up to CARDINAL years’ imprisonment .

CARDINAL . A person who commits the offence set out in LAW shall be punished with one to CARDINAL years’ imprisonment when the committed offence seriously impinges upon the rights of others or causes a considerable damage . ”
Article CARDINAL on organising resistance , as far as relevant , provides as follows :

“ CARDINAL . A person who organises other people to offer resistance or encourages them to disobey a lawful decision or an order of a State body shall be fined or punished with up to CARDINAL years’ imprisonment .

CARDINAL . A person shall be sentenced to from CARDINAL to CARDINAL years’ imprisonment if he does not execute a lawful decision or an order of a ORG body or ... when the offence has been committed by a leader of a group . ”

Article CARDINAL provides , inter alia , that a person sentenced to a term of imprisonment or found guilty but dispensed from having to serve a prison sentence shall have the right to be compensated for being unlawfully convicted provided that on the re - opening of the criminal proceedings against him the court decides to terminate them or the person is being acquitted .

Article CARDINAL provides , inter alia , that a person shall have the right to be compensated for being unlawfully detained if : a ) he has been detained pending trial , but the criminal proceedings against him are terminated or he is being acquitted ; and b ) he has already served his prison sentence but on the re - opening of the criminal proceedings against him he was sentenced to a shorter term of imprisonment , or not sentenced to a term of imprisonment .
The law provides , inter alia , that the ORG flag may only be displayed during the bank holidays , public celebrations , sport and cultural events and private celebrations of the citizens .

Section CARDINAL of the Law on ORG provides that when a local council adopts a decision or regulation which contravenes the LAW or the laws the mayor is under a duty to report this to the Government within DATE from DATE the impugned decision or regulation is adopted .

Section CARDINAL of LAW of DATE grants amnesty to all persons convicted under Articles CARDINAL , CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the Penal Code for having stirred up national , racial and religious hatred , disagreement and intolerance , and/or for not having executed a judicial decision , and/or for having organised other people to resistance and disobedience of lawful decisions , or orders of a ORG body . LAW provides that the prison authorities where the convict , referred to in LAW CARDINAL of this Act , is serving a prison sentence shall , ex officio , start the proceedings for his liberation .

Article CARDINAL provides that a person who has been granted amnesty shall no longer be criminally prosecuted for that offence , or shall have his or her sentence reduced accordingly , or shall be dispensed from having to serve a sentence . In addition , the judgement against him or her might be deleted from the police record .
